frameDefinitions: A Theme changes location with respect to a salient location, which can be expressed by a Source, Path, Goal, Area, Direction, Path_shape, or Distance, as shown in the examples below: ''  'Start your ascent from Achintree Farm in Glen Nevis.'
In this frame a Theme moves in a certain Direction which is often determined by gravity or other natural, physical forces.
An Agent enacts an Action that is intended to be performed again at one or more later Occasions.
The Self_mover, a living being, moves under its own direction along a Path.
The words in this frame describe the 'fictive' motion of a stationary Road.
A Self_mover intentionally moves in a Directionon a Path relative to landmark that is neither the Source nor the Goal of the overall motion.
frameExamples: Start your <t>ascent</t> from Achintree Farm in Glen Nevis.
I <t>practiced</t> my song for the play.
She <t>walked</t> along the road for a while.
The long mountain road <t>meandered</t> through the woods.
Ambrose Powell <t>forded</t> over on one horse, and we drove the others after him.
listRoleDefinitions: This is the object which moves. In many sentences this role will be expressed as something which moves under its own power. However, this role is not <ment>required</ment> to be an animate mover, so it is different from Self_mover.

Any expression which implies a definite starting-point of motion expresses the frame element <fen>Source</fen>. In prepositional phrases, the prepositional object expresses the starting point of motion. In particles, the starting point of motion is understood from context.
Any description of a trajectory of motion which is neither a <fen>Source</fen> nor a <fen>Goal</fen> (see below) expresses the frame element <fen>Path</fen>, including directional expressions:
Any expression which tells where the <fen>Theme</fen> ends up as a result of the motion expresses the frame element Goal.
Any expression which characterizes the extent of motion expresses the frame element <fen>Distance</fen>.
This frame element is used for expressions which describe a general area in which motion takes place when the motion is understood to be irregular and not to consist of a single linear path.
The configuration formed by the entire <fen>Path</fen> of the <fen>Theme</fen>, taken simultaneously.
The direction in which the <fen>Theme</fen> goes.
The time at which the motion takes place.
The <fen>Place</fen> is where the motion (which is specified by a <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen> or <fen>Goal</fen>) is located.
This role identifies the general <fen>Area</fen> in which motion takes place when the motion is understood to be irregular or not to consist of a single, linear path.
The <fen>Goal</fen> is the location the <fen>Theme</fen> ends up in (often unintentionally).
<fen>Path</fen> refers to (a part of) the ground over which the <fen>Theme</fen> travels  or to a landmark past which the <fen>Theme</fen> travels.
The <fen>Theme</fen> is the entity that changes location.
The <fen>Source</fen> is the location the <fen>Theme</fen> occupies before the Motion occurs.
The direction of motion of the <fen>Theme</fen>.  <fen>Direction</fen> characterizes the <fen>Path</fen> of motion according to some system of orientation, most often that imposed by gravity.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the Motion occurs.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where motion specified by <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen> or <fen>Goal</fen> occurs.
This role identifies the <fen>Action</fen> that the <fen>Agent</fen> performs intentionally in order to prepare for a later <fen>Occasion</fen>.
The <fen>Agent</fen> performs the <fen>Action</fen> in preparation for later performances of the same type.
The later enactment or enactments that the <fen>Agent</fen> expects to perform. Note that the <fen>Agent</fen> does not have to have specific <fen>Occasion</fen>s in mind.
This role identifies the time when the <fen>Agent</fen> practices.
This role identifies the place where the practicing occurs.
<fen>Self_mover</fen> is the living being which moves under its own power. Normally it is expressed as an external argument.

<fen>Source</fen> is used for any expression which implies a definite starting-point of motion.
In prepositional phrases, the prepositional object expresses the starting point of motion.  With particles, the starting point of motion is understood from context.
<fen>Path</fen> is used for any description of a trajectory of motion which is neither a <fen>Source</fen> nor a <fen>Goal</fen>.  This includes 'middle of path'' expressions.
<fen>Goal</fen> is used for any expression which tells where the <fen>Self_mover</fen> ends up as a result of the motion.

<fen>Area</fen> is used for expressions which describe a general area in which motion takes place when the motion is understood to be irregular and not to consist of a single linear path.  Note that this role should not be used for cases when the same phrase could be used with the same meaning with a non-motion target, since these should be annotated with the <fen>Place</fen> FE.
The direction that the <fen>Self_mover</fen> heads in during the motion.
The time when the motion occurs.

The <fen>Place</fen> is the location within which a defined motion takes place.  Any specified or implied  <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen> or <fen>Goal</fen> should designate a location contained with the <fen>Place</fen>.  This role can be differentiated from <fen>Area</fen> by the fact that the annotated phrase can be used in the same meaning with non-motion targets.

Any expression which implies a definite starting-point of the <fen>Road</fen>. In prepositional phrases, the prepositional object expresses the starting point of motion. In particles, the starting point of motion is understood from context.
The trajectory that would be followed by one moving on the <fen>Road</fen>.
Any expression which tells where the fictive mover travelling along a <fen>Road</fen> would end up.

A physical path that a virtual moving entity can be imagined to travel along.
<fex name='Road'>The bike trail</fex> <t>zigzagged</t> through the woods.
This frame element is used for expressions which describe a general area in which motion takes place when the motion is understood to be irregular and not to consist of a single linear path.
The configuration formed by the entire <fen>Path</fen> along the <fen>Road</fen>.
The direction in which a 'fictive' mover would travel along a <fen>Road</fen>.

The time when the fictive motion takes place.  This may describe the time when the <fen>Road</fen> or a particular piece of the <fen>Road</fen> existed, or it may implicitly describe the time when an actual motion event occurred on the <fen>Road</fen>.
The <fen>Place</fen> is where the motion (which is specified by a <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen> or <fen>Goal</fen>) is located.
This is a sentient being or a vehicle steered by a sentient being which moves.
Any expression which implies a definite starting-point of motion expresses the frame element <fen>Source</fen>.
Any description of a trajectory of motion which is neither a <fen>Source</fen> nor a <fen>Goal</fen> expresses the frame element <fen>Path</fen>, excluding directional expressions:
Any expression which indicates where the <fen>Self_mover</fen> ends up as a result of the motion expresses the frame element <fen>Goal</fen>.
The configuration formed by the entire <fen>Path</fen> of the <fen>Self_mover</fen>, taken simultaneously.
The direction in which the <fen>Self_mover</fen> goes.
The time at which the motion takes place.
The <fen>Place</fen> is where the motion (which is specified by a <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen> or <fen>Goal</fen>) is located.
listRoleExamples: <fex>Kim</fex> crossed through the woods.
The cat crossed the street <fex>from her yard</fex>.
The bikers crisscrossed <fex>through the desert</fex>.
The children hopped <fex>into the neighbor's yard</fex>.
I leaped <fex>twenty feet</fex> before slipping and falling.
The bikers crisscrossed <fex>the desert</fex>.
He circled downward <fex>in a spiral</fex>.
The frogs jumped <fex>down</fex> through the meadow.
They crisscrossed the country <fex>in April</fex>.
Soot-contaminated snow falls <fex>in Slovakia's mountainous regions</fex>.
The rivals both fell backwards <fex>into empty space</fex>.
The boys plummeted <fex>down the stairs</fex> into the basement.
In 1977, <fex> Nigel</fex> plunged to his death in his car on a mountain road in southern France.
The man toppled <fex>from the passenger seat</fex> into the road.
I hope your egg does n't fall <fex>down</fex> .
<fex>In 1977</fex> Nigel plunged to his death in his car on a mountain road in southern France.
<fex>In the kitchen</fex>, the towel dropped onto the floor.
Little Dieter practiced <fex>playing the piano</fex> all day.
<fex>For our brother's wedding</fex> we had to rehearse the dinner twenty times.
We practiced the play <fex>on Tuesday</fex>.
Our band practices <fex>on the football field</fex>.
<fex>Fred</fex> crawled the narrow passage.
The cat ran <fex>out of the house</fex>.
The scouts hiked <fex>through the desert</fex>.
The children skipped <fex>into the park</fex>.
The mouse scurried <fex>about</fex>.
You should walk <fex>south</fex> about a block .
The hitchhikers walked <fex>in the middle of the road</fex>.
The Way descends <fex>from the City of the Peak</fex> through a dense forest.
Valencia angles <fex>across the number streets</fex>.
<fex>Where</fex> does Interstate 80 enter the city ?
The paths crisscrossed <fex>the desert</fex>.
The cavern descended <fex>in a spiral</fex>.
The pass dips <fex>down</fex> about 2000 feet, and then <fex>back up</fex> again.
<fex>Thousands of years ago</fex>, the Roman roads criss-crossed this landscape.
<fex>In the mountains</fex>, Highway 60 winds and swerves a lot, so we lost a couple of hours from my estimate.
<fex>We</fex> drive down dusty roads, forded through a stream, and tried to get up a mountainside on a rocky road.
We forded <fex>from the island</fex> to the mainland.
We decided to cut <fex>through the forest</fex>.
I'll cut across the Sahara desert <fex>up to Algeria and Morocco</fex>.
We followed the trail (which is well marked with cairns) and then cut <fex>west</fex> across a grassy meadow for about 1000 feet to the crest of  the nearby saddle lying below North Peak.
The Federal Army of the Potomac forded the river <fex>in August 1862</fex>.
The common brook is best forded <fex>south of the hut</fex>.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: the Centre for Anthropobiology and Genomics of Toulouse
